ii REVIEW OF MARITIME TRANSPORT 2012 NOTE The Review of Maritime Transport is a recurrent publication prepared by the UNCTAD secretariat since 1968 with the aim of fostering the transparency of maritime markets and analysing relevant developments. FOREWORD xiii FOREWORD Maritime transport is the backbone of international trade and a key engine driving globalization. Around 80 per cent of global trade by volume and over 70 per cent by value is carried by sea and is handled by ports worldwide; these shares are even higher in the case of most developing countries. UNCTAD’s Review of Maritime Transport(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:23)(cid:23)(cid:125)(cid:92)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:88)(cid:83)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:73)(cid:73)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:90)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:79)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:16)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) regulatory and legal frameworks. Many of these factors remained relevant in 2012 and, depending on how they evolve, they could impact dramatically on the global economic and trade outlook. This chapter covers developments from January 2011 to June 2012, and where possible up to October 2012. Section A reviews the overall performance of the global economy and world merchandise trade. Section B considers developments in world seaborne trade volumes and examines trends unfolding in the economic sectors and activities that generate demand for shipping services, including oil and gas, mining, agriculture and steel production. Section C highlights selected trends that are currently transforming the landscape of international shipping and seaborne trade, focusing mainly on climate (cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:73)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:74)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:389)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3) and the rising bunker fuel prices and operating costs.

A different picture emerges, however, when one considers the contribution of these market segments to the value of world seaborne trade. While recent data, including for 2011, are not readily available, existing estimates for 2007 may provide some insight into the distribution of world seaborne trade by value and allow for some comparisons to be made. Table 1.5 (b) features estimated annual deadweight (dwt-miles), which are calculated by ton-miles multiplying the number of voyages between each port by the distance and individual vessel dwt. The sanctions have a direct impact on this country’s oil exports as well as on the oil trade that passes through the Strait of Hormuz. An escalation of these geopolitical tensions could lead to a shutdown of the Strait, which in turn would create oil shortages and raise oil prices to potentially extreme levels, including the range of $200–$400.40 Although temporary waivers have been issued for a number of countries, concerns remain with respect to the likely severe impact of the sanctions, including those enacted by the European Union. These latter sanctions prohibit insurers in Europe – marine insurers are to a large extent based in Europe and the United States – from issuing or maintaining insurance to tankers involved in servicing the oil trade of the Islamic Republic of Iran. Pressure is particularly high for some key crude importers, which could be forced to provide sovereign guarantees to tankers. In a separate development, tanker trade has also been affected by rising operating costs resulting from the higher oil and bunker fuel prices that prevailed in 2011. Tanker operators had to reduce speed to optimize fuel consumption and also absorb excess tonnage capacity. Slow steaming has been implemented in the tanker trade, with most voyages taking place at an average of 13 knots (compared to 14 knots), and at 10–11 knots when sailing in ballast (see also (cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:125)(cid:38)(cid:12)(cid:17)

Over the past few years LNG has been one of the fastest-growing cargoes owing to the increasing interest in LNG as a greener alternative to other fossil fuels. Interest in LNG heightened in 2011 as the fallout from the disaster in Japan highlighted the risk of a great reliance on nuclear power over the long term. SELECTED EMERGING TRENDS AFFECTING INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING Against a background of economic uncertainty, faltering demand and the burden of ship tonnage overcapacity (see chapter 2), the shipping industry is also confronted by a rapidly changing operating environment, in which some trends are reshaping the industry’s future and altering global seaborne trade patterns. Shipping and logistics will need to address these developments to adapt to the new realities and remain operational and competitive. Featuring high on the list of these trends are: (cid:115)(cid:3) Climate change; (cid:115)(cid:3) (cid:54)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:73)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:74)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:389)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:3) (cid:3) trade patterns; (cid:115)(cid:3) Rising bunker fuel prices and operating costs; (cid:115)(cid:3) Maritime piracy (see chapters 5 and 3);65 (cid:115)(cid:3) Growing momentum of sustainability imperatives (see chapter 6).66 While all these issues warrant due consideration, the following section focuses on three developments that entail particularly long-term implications, namely climate change, shifting global economic mass and trade patterns, and rising fuel and operating costs. 1. Transport and the climate change challenge Climate change is one of the greatest challenges facing our societies, economic structures and environmental (cid:86)(cid:92)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:36)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:78)(cid:3) (cid:80)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:77)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) by exacerbating other interconnected global problems, including poverty, food shortages, water scarcity, energy insecurity and environmental degradation. Finally, another important concern for the container industry was dealt with in 2011 as the call by the shipping and port industries for mandatory controls on the weighing of freight containers received full attention at the International Maritime Organization the greenhouse gas Transportation and (GHG) emissions that it generates are at the centre stage of the current climate change debate. While the entire sector needs to reduce its carbon footprint, international shipping, in particular, has attracted

CHAPTER 1: DEVELOPMENTS IN INTERNATIONAL SEABORNE TRADE 23 attention because the GHG emissions generated by this sector are not covered under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Another reason for this heightened interest is the renewed opportunity provided by the current climate negotiations under UNFCCC and IMO to (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:87)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:388)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:74)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:17)(cid:3) Some regulatory measures focusing on technical and operational aspects of international shipping have recently been adopted by IMO while other measures, such as market-based instruments, are still being considered (see chapters 5 and 6). Mitigation action is also gathering momentum among the shipping and port industries with a number of measures being planned or having already been implemented (see chapter 6). However, although mitigation action (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) effectively address climate change and its related (cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:36)(cid:71)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3) on a good understanding of risks and vulnerabilities is fundamental to help minimize the effects of unmitigated trade. While climate change on adaptation action in maritime transport is increasingly recognized as important, it should be noted that it is a newcomer to the climate change policy debate and has so far attracted much less interest than mitigation. transport and Within the transport sector, the special case of (cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:58)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87) of world trade by volume being carried by sea, (cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:388)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:78)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:74)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:92) chains and constitute engines of economic growth. At the same time, these key infrastructural assets are vulnerable to climate change impacts and associated risks, given their location in coastal zones, low-lying areas and deltas. Risks for maritime transport include accelerated coastal erosion, port and coastal road inundation or (cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:69)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) increased dredging, restrictions on access to docks, deterioration of conditions and problems with the structural integrity of pavements and railway tracks within port areas and related hinterland connections.67 In addition to these impacts on physical infrastructure, climate change also affects shipping volumes and costs, cargo loading and capacity, sailing and/ or loading schedules, storage and warehousing.68 These impacts are likely to impose costs that will be correlated to the degree of exposure and vulnerability, as well as constraints on the adaptive capacity. interconnectedness Furthermore, greater global and economic integration with supply chains acting as transmission channels entail additional costs. A localized impact on ports can have ripple effects that extend beyond borders to affect industries, stakeholders and economies in distant locations. Although not necessarily driven by climate change, supply chain disruptions resulting from damage to ports caused by natural disasters in Japan and Thailand in 2011 provide a poignant illustration. The implications of any damage or disruption to transport networks, including ports, can be particularly challenging for the transport and trade of developing countries such as small island developing States (SIDS). The challenge for SIDS is of greater magnitude given their high economic, geographic and climatic vulnerabilities and their generally limited adaptive capacity.69 In this context, building the capacities of developing countries, including SIDS, with a view to reducing their vulnerability and managing disaster risks is crucial and should be pursued as a matter of priority.70 Assessing with any certainty the costs for ports and their hinterland connections associated with (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:87)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:55)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) no doubt, however, that these impacts can reach extreme proportions in ports and port cities.71 A study by OECD assessed the exposure of the world’s (cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:389)(cid:82)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:24)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3) estimated the total value of assets exposed across all 136 port cities examined to be $3 trillion.72 A more recent study examining the same 136 port megacities has found that, assuming a sea-level rise of 0.5 metres by 2050, the value of exposed assets may be as high as $28 trillion.73 These costs are rising in tandem with ever increasing urbanization, population growth, investment in port and transport infrastructure, and wealth expansion around coastal areas. Much of this growth is being generated by South–South and intraregional trade.96 Some observers argue that the winner of globalization will be Asia, with rising intra-Asian trade becoming the focus of the global economy. South–South interregional trade is also expected to grow and gather momentum.97 Supply chains, greater integration in the world economy, growing regional concentration and a shift of technology will all propel East Asian countries (led by China) to become the largest trading bloc in 2015, surpassing the areas of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and the Euro.98 Such a development will have tangible implications for global transport and trade patterns. One recent analysis predicts that in 2015 China will be the top exporter and importer and that by 2030 the world’s largest trade corridor will not involve the United States or Europe, but will instead extend from the advanced to the emerging Asia of Thailand and Viet Nam.99 (cid:44)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:24)(cid:19)(cid:3) (cid:25)(cid:19)(cid:125) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:91)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) from advanced Asia will go to emerging Asia, thus reinforcing the move eastwards and South–South trade.100 (cid:44)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:77)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:74)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:15)(cid:3) freight transport is expected to expand. 26 REVIEW OF MARITIME TRANSPORT 2012 3. Rising bunker fuel prices and operating costs Bunker fuel prices increased in tandem with global oil prices, as shown by the price of 380 centistokes (cid:11)(cid:70)(cid:54)(cid:87)(cid:12)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:54)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:23)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) reach $647 per ton in 2011. Higher fuel costs have a disproportionate effect on transportation companies, as fuel is a necessary cost input. In the tanker market, for example, the Republic of Korean (cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:54)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:75)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:54)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:80)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:53)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:88)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) costs, low freight rates and the costs associated with piracy attacks against its vessels.105 In the liner industry, the overall loss in 2011 was estimated at over (cid:7)(cid:25)(cid:125)(cid:69)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:17)106 In a context of increasingly higher costs and weak (cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:3) (cid:77)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:3) is becoming important. Relevant cost-cutting measures include speed management through slow (cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:77)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) selection of the most economical routing options. Among these strategies, slow steaming has evolved into a key cost-cutting measure that reduces bunker fuel consumption and helps absorb capacity. Today, slow steaming is implemented across various market segments and in particular container trade, which relied heavily on this strategy during the 2008/2009 (cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:55)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:74)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:3)(cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:87)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:22)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:20)(cid:3) on a number of mainlane trades107 and has continued to reduce sailing speed from 24–25 knots to 21 knots (slow steaming), 18 knots (extra-slow steaming) and 15 knots (super-slow steaming).108 In the tanker trade, slow steaming has been implemented with most voyages occurring at an average of 13 knots (compared to 14 knots), and 10–11 knots when sailing in ballast (see also previous section on crude oil shipments and chapter 2).109 Some argue that slow steaming has its limitations and that it may not be advisable to implement it in all cases. First, slow steaming may be better limited to a few long-haul routes and not used for short-haul ones. Second, there is a need to assess the implications of (cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:92)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:17)(cid:3) Furthermore, increased transit time, especially for the dominant leg, may not be acceptable for supply chains, as shown by a study investigating the merits of slow steaming.110 This study argued that other factors need to be accounted for, including the auxiliary bunker costs and the sensitivity of demand to transit time. Figures for January 2010 indicated a limited use of slow steaming on the Europe–South American (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:22)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:12)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:27)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) services operating slow steaming on those between Europe and the Far East. The study concludes that a differentiated strategy by shipping lines of sailing at a different speed depending on the leg, or of using hubs instead of direct services maybe recommended. Such differentiated strategy would also take into account the sensitivity of demand to transit time, such as, for example, by distinguishing between frozen and dry and fresh products. While slow steaming is viewed by many as a short-term (cid:388)(cid:91)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:16)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:80)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:44)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:90)(cid:3) of current developments in the energy sector, growing demand, constrained and uncertain supply, as well as ongoing geopolitical risks affecting oil producing regions, oil prices and therefore bunker fuel costs will not doubt continue to trend upward.111 Interestingly however, the historical correlation between bunker and crude prices seems to have changed slightly in 2011, as the rise in bunker prices exceeded that of crude oil. A potential reason for this could be that the large ship deliveries of recent years have increased demand for marine fuels against a slower supply.112

The price differential with residual fuel is currently (cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:24)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:58)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) use technology such as cleaning systems for exhaust gas (scrubbers), the effective widespread use of such scrubbers remains uncertain. These developments raise concerns about their potential economic impact on shipping, especially at a time when fuel costs account for more than two thirds of operational ship expenditure. Other concerns relate to the potential for inducing an undesirable modal shift. Recent studies supported by the European Community Shipowners’ Associations (ECSA) have (cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:74)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:19)(cid:17)(cid:20)(cid:125) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) sulphur fuel could result in a modal shift from water to surface transport which could be detrimental for local shipping and the environment. This concern is shared with respect to trade in the Great Lakes of Canada and the United States. fuel consumption management To sum up, rising energy prices and fuel costs remain a great challenge for the shipping industry in view, in particular, of rising demand, supply pressures and increasing environmental regulation. Cost control and is essential and may involve a range of strategies. These may include speed management through slow steaming, selection of the most economical routing options and technology-based solutions. These strategies will impact on the design of vessels and propulsion systems, as well as on other technology-related strategies and operational measures. While these may apply differently, depending on the vessel and type of operations, overall a combination of technology-based (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) to help address rising fuel and operational costs. As (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:92)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) optimize fuel consumption, in view in particular of the more stringent environmental regulatory framework and given the concerns over climate change, new options and solutions are being increasingly developed and tested. The trends discussed above are all interconnected and entail both challenges and opportunities for the shipping industry. By altering costs, prices and comparative advantages, these developments and related impacts on shipping and seaborne trade can greatly determine countries’ trade performance and competitiveness. Improved understanding of these issues and their impacts, both individually and in (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:69)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3) all stakeholders, including policy makers, investors, transport planners, operators and managers.

The IPCC published a new set of scenarios in 2000 for use in the Third Assessment Report (Special Report on Emissions Scenarios - SRES). A2 storyline and scenario family: a very heterogeneous world with continuously increasing global population and regionally oriented economic growth that is more fragmented and slower than in other storylines. B2 storyline and scenario family: a world in which the emphasis is on local solutions to economic, social, and environmental sustainability, with continuously increasing population (lower than A2) and intermediate economic development. Chinese shipowners and iron ore producers opposed the entry of the Brazilian Valemax ships into Chinese ports, arguing that the operation of such large ships might not be safe, and fearing that Vale could gain monopolistic control of the supply chain for iron ore. Ports would also need to expand stockpiling capacity to store the imported ore.3 Vale is planning to take delivery of 35 such ships by (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:22)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:7)(cid:23)(cid:17)(cid:21)(cid:125)(cid:69)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:17)(cid:3) The Valemax ships are built in shipyards in the Republic (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:46)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:38)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:46)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:83)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) South-South trade and collaboration between Brazil and China, several industry observers expressed hope that the ban for Valemax ships to enter Chinese ports would soon be lifted.4 History has shown, however, that attempts by exporters to control the maritime supply chain have often been short-lived, and in the longer term the traditional shipowners may resume their role as providers of maritime transport services. Oil tankers (cid:55)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:125)(cid:69)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) dwt in January 2012. A part of this tonnage is used for storage, rather than for transporting oil. For example, in March 2012, the world’s second-largest oil tanker was booked by Petroleo Brasileiro to be deployed as a storage facility. Increasing production in Latin America has spurred demand for more ships to store crude oil.5(cid:3)(cid:55)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:70)(cid:78)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3) possible future shortage of oil – for example, due to (cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:389)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:51)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:42)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:73)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:44)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:80)(cid:15)(cid:3) the increase in the use of ships to store oil helps to reduce the oversupply of tonnage. In the medium- term future, the release of the stored oil will reduce the demand for oil transport and at the same time will increase available tanker capacity, again resulting in an oversupply of tonnage. CHAPTER 2: STRUCTURE, OWNERSHIP AND REGISTRATION OF THE WORLD FLEET 39 The supply–demand balance is more favourable for shipowners of product tankers, for which fewer orders have been placed in recent years, but demand has increased due to longer distances between regions of supply and demand. For the case of India, for example, it has been argued that a relaxation of the cabotage restrictions would help promote trans-shipment in Indian ports.13 In Nigeria, the issuance of waivers for foreign providers of cabotage services has in practice become the rule rather than an exception.14 Other countries have chosen to maintain a more restrictive policy, with a view to promoting national shipbuilding and the employment of national seafarers. Owners from Bermuda, Brazil and the Isle of Man specialize mostly in large ships, notably tankers and dry bulk carriers. Container shipping operators The top 20 carriers B. OWNERSHIP AND OPERATION OF THE WORLD FLEET 1. Ship-owning countries Among the top 35 ship-owning economies, there are 17 in Asia, 14 in Europe and 4 in the Americas The largest container ship operators in January 2012 continue to be Maersk Line (Denmark), MSC (Switzerland) and CMA CGM (France). Investing in circles (cid:38)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:87)(cid:3) from economies of scale. The pressure to reduce costs is increased by historically low freight rates. However, building more and larger ships also adds to the general oversupply of capacity, thus putting further downward pressure on the freight rates. While an investment in larger ships may make sense for an individual company, for the industry as a whole this actually leads to a vicious cycle of more oversupply of tonnage and a further (cid:90)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:41)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:112)(cid:3) perspective this pattern could also be considered as a virtuous cycle, where technological progress and (cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:83)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3) in turn help to promote trade and investment in larger (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:92)(cid:16)(cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:86)(cid:17) Not all carriers have shown procyclical investment patterns. For new orders, the (cid:83)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:77)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:29)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:92)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:28)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) dwt per year, which is 2.5 times as much as the annual new orders placed between 2009 and 2011.30 It is, largely, the orders placed prior to 2009 that are the cause of the present boom in deliveries. Based on the current order book, deliveries in 2012 are expected to be even higher than last year’s historical record; (cid:26)(cid:22)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) during 2012 were ordered in 2008 or earlier.31 Only in (cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:22)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:90)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:28)(cid:3)(cid:388)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) also lead to a decline in shipbuilding. Chinese shipyards and Chinese traders have a common interest in continuing deliveries of new ships by Chinese shipyards. The building activities maintain employment in shipbuilding, and the delivered tonnage ensures a high supply of maritime transport capacity, (cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:91)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3) Shipowners, on the other hand, have reportedly expressed concerns that a continued oversupply of ships could prove devastating for them.32 In the longer term, in view of the reduced numbers of new orders, shipyards in most countries have been forced to reduce their capacity.33 An exception is the Philippines, which is expanding its shipbuilding capacity; factors contributing to this expansion include (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:43)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:77)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:11)(cid:53)(cid:72)(cid:83)(cid:88)(cid:69)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:46)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:12)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) reportedly planning to hire 10,000 additional workers for its facility in Subic Bay.34 India, too, is expected to expand its shipbuilding and repair capacity by 2015.35

Slow steaming in container shipping Since 2008, container shipping companies have systematically reduced the speed of their services by introducing slow steaming. This has allowed them to absorb additional vessel capacity, thus reducing the (cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:44)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:79)(cid:92) reduce fuel consumption. When initially introduced, slow steaming did not meet much opposition from shippers, because during the economic downturn many importers were not particularly concerned about replenishing their (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:36)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:24)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:79) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:17)43 Estimates for the average speed of shipping lines point to 15 to 20 knots for different levels of slow steaming. 10 000 dwt and conventional general cargo vessels of less (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:24)(cid:15)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:71)(cid:90)(cid:87)(cid:17) The inventory cost (capital, depreciation) of the goods that spend more time en route may well be higher than the cost savings made by the carriers. Shippers, who have to bear the inventory costs, have accordingly this situation. Nevertheless, complained about shippers have also realized that slow steaming may improve service reliability, and in the end may not be too concerned about the speed of delivery.45 A further reduction of service speed would not make technological or economic sense – engines would suffer, and the savings made in fuel reduction would be outweighed by additional operating costs resulting from the need to deploy additional ships. Returning to the previous higher speeds appears unlikely, too, as businesses have now adapted to the inventory held on the ships, and in view of the continuing oversupply of tonnage, the carriers have no room to re-absorb additional capacity should from slow steaming. It appears that the current speeds may become the norm, with high speeding being considered as a form of premium service. it be released

Container freight rates Having experienced one of the steepest freight rate cuts in history in 2008, the recovery remains sluggish in 2011. Furthermore, with a growth rate predicted at (cid:21)(cid:24)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:16)(cid:27)(cid:15)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:3)(cid:55)(cid:40)(cid:56)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:21)(cid:15)(cid:3) large-scale capacity is continuing to enter this market segment.6 Container ship operators entering the reefer business The decline in freight rates in the container shipping business increasingly puts competitive pressures on specialized reefers. Refrigerated cargo is used (cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3) some of the idle capacity in the business. This trend (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:88)(cid:92)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:112)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:69)(cid:82)(cid:82)(cid:78)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3) contains an increasing share of vessels with large reefer capacity (see also chapter 2).7 Industry-leader reefers such as Star Reefers have described 2011, as for 2010, as one of the poorest years in the industry’s history, companies being hit hard by the low freight rates and increased competition from container ship operators.8 The spot market rates for larger reefer ships reached an average of 43 cents per cubic feet per 30 days in 2011, following 42 cents in 2010.9 The near collapse of banana exports from Ecuador and Central America since April 2011 brought additional stress to reefer freight rates. Although a strong growth in demand for the transport of perishable goods is being predicted, the shipping industry will most likely also experience an ongoing cargo shift from specialized reefers to container ships. International container lines are constantly introducing new regular services for the transportation (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:74)(cid:82)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:77)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) centres with the largest consumer markets, such as Europe and North America. (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) world demand for oil and maritime transport services are both strongly linked to overall economic growth. During times of economic growth, the demand for maritime transport services and oil increases substantially, possibly outweighing, in parallel, their demand and supply balance and thus leading to price increases. In the past, seaborne trade has grown approximately two times faster than the world’s gross domestic product (GDP) (see also chapter 1). (cid:36)(cid:79)(cid:80)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:26)(cid:125)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:22)(cid:24)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) cent of seaborne petroleum trade, were transported through the Persian Gulf in 2011, making it the world’s busiest shipping strait for this product.14 In terms of (cid:89)(cid:82)(cid:92)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:26)(cid:22)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:79)(cid:71)(cid:112)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:22)(cid:15)(cid:26)(cid:21)(cid:21)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:92)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3) crude carrier (VLCC) trips have passed through the Persian Gulf.15 Transport restrictions due to the oil embargo on the Islamic Republic of Iran could, therefore, heavily affect the world tanker shipping market as a whole. The cut in transport demand for oil from the Islamic Republic of Iran was expected to trigger freight rate drops. However, prices on the Persian Gulf–Europe route, as an example, rose from 37 to 44 on the Worldscale from February to April (cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:21)(cid:3) (cid:11)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:125) (cid:22)(cid:17)(cid:22)(cid:12)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:55)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:54)(cid:68)(cid:88)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:3) (cid:36)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:76)(cid:68)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3) ramped up oil production to compensate for the drop in exports from the Islamic Republic of Iran. Other oil (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:74)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:58)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3) Africa, the Caribbean and the North Sea region. The routes from these sources to Asia are much longer than those from the Persian Gulf, thus increasing tanker ton miles and capacity utilization rates.16 With oil-consuming countries such as the United States and China building up their energy reservoirs, additional vessels have been taken out of the spot market.17 Freight rates on routes from West Africa were exposed to volatilities in 2011, with drops in the West Africa– North-West Europe route from 107 on the Worldscale in March to 69 in August. They contribute about two thirds of the world dry bulk trade. Minor bulks include fertilizers, steel products, construction materials such as cement and aluminium, non-grain agricultural products, forest products and sundry minerals (for example, phosphate rock), these adding another third to the total dry bulk seaborne trade. These goods are most commonly shipped by the smaller Handymax and Handysize vessels.29 The increasing vessel utilization rate reinforced hopes of a market recovery in mid-2011. Transport demand and supply During different stages in the shipping market cycle, diverging demand and supply lead to substantial (cid:389)(cid:88)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:88)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:44)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:87) rates and the volume of new ship orders often evolve in parallel. In times of high freight rates, ship owners tend to invest in new vessel capacity, this being also due to an increased willingness of banks to lend money, thus expanding the orderbook. With an increasing supply of (cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:92)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:88)(cid:83) for cargo, thus reducing the industry’s appetite to invest in new vessel capacity.50 With this interplay between supply and demand in mind, this section will assess selected indicators for the two elements. Growth rates of both supply (vessel capacity) and (cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:82)(cid:79)(cid:88)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:12)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:125)(cid:22)(cid:17)(cid:26)(cid:17)(cid:3) In all three segments, vessel capacity has grown faster than the seaborne trade volume. Between 2000 and 2011, bulk carrier supply expanded almost two times faster than the transport demand. In the tanker segment, this gap was even larger, with a vessel capacity increasing 2.3 times faster than the transported volume of goods. Developing to Oceania achieved a transport cost share reduction (cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:3) (cid:20)(cid:20)(cid:17)(cid:26)(cid:125) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:20)(cid:28)(cid:28)(cid:23)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:27)(cid:17)(cid:25)(cid:125) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:19)(cid:15)(cid:3) while the developing nations of America and Asia have already reached a transport cost share approximately (cid:20)(cid:125) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:82)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:36)(cid:81)(cid:3) exception from this trend of convergence is developing Africa, with a stable ratio of freight costs to import value (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:19)(cid:17)(cid:28)(cid:125)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:90)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:22)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:19)(cid:17) Low productivity, high charges and congestions in many African ports are some of the factors explaining these discrepancies.51 Vessel operators tend to pass these costs on to shippers when calculating their freight rates. In addition, African ports are often (cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:78)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) transport infrastructure.52 On the shipping side, the UNCTAD Liner Shipping Connectivity Index (LSCI) (see also chapter 4) reveals a lack of economies of scale and competition in many African countries. African ports cannot host the largest ships that offer the most competitive freight rates. The relatively small number of alternative operators serving most African ports results in low competitive pressure, thus keeping freight rates high. Trade imbalances are another factor contributing to higher freight rates in Africa. With an import surplus for containerized cargo, and exports that mostly comprise bulk goods, which are transported by tankers and dry bulk carriers, vessels can often only be fully utilized on one route.53 (cid:38)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:3) freight rate for a single trip that compensates their expenditures for both the fronthaul and the backhaul lanes. C. POLICY OPTIONS TO REDUCE MARITIME TRANSPORT COSTS Transport costs remain an important component of (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:74)(cid:82)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) consumer. High maritime transport costs for imported goods impact the price level of the basket of consumer goods. Conversely, excessive freight rates for exports affect the trade competitiveness of the products of a country in the global markets. Hence, countries may (cid:90)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:83)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:68)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:69)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) outbound maritime transport costs in their trade with partners, as discussed below.

CHAPTER 3: FREIGHT RATES AND MARITIME TRANSPORT COSTS 75 The freight rate cost analysis, conducted for the case of (cid:68)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:19)(cid:15)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:19)(cid:125)(cid:71)(cid:90)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:11)(cid:388)(cid:74)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:125)(cid:22)(cid:17)(cid:26)(cid:12)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:77)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3) elements of freight rates and can assist when identifying policy measures aimed at reducing individual cost drivers. The policy options available to a single country that could produce a substantial reduction of freight rates are, nonetheless, limited. Vessel operators can choose worldwide between many alternative suppliers when procuring the goods and services they need for their vessel operations, thus levelling comparative cost advantages of individual destinations. In most large ports, for instance, cheap fuelling services are offered and, even if these services are not provided, a ship can choose to use bunkering services at an alternative destination. If one country alone were able to offer (cid:74)(cid:82)(cid:82)(cid:71)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:89)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) level of other nations, these competitive advantages (cid:90)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:69)(cid:68)(cid:69)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:389)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) or from that country. Hosting competitive insurance service providers, for example, will not assist a country to reduce its maritime transport costs. These cost (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:89)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:78)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) freight rates for all routes a vessel operator serves within his shipping network. It estimates, for example, that the costs for United (cid:54)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:16)(cid:389)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:3) (cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:21)(cid:19)(cid:20)(cid:19)(cid:3) (cid:90)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:88)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:21)(cid:17)(cid:26)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:82)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:74)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:389)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:17)54 Opening cabotage to international shipping lines is another policy option. The entrance of new market players may reduce freight rates for shippers and lead to better and more diverse services. However, most countries often give cabotage rights exclusively to domestic carriers with the aim of protecting and promoting the national shipping industry. Another measure to support cabotage is the expansion of a country’s feeder port network. This will facilitate access of traders to coastal shipping and encourage them to shift from land to maritime transport. The increased volumes may lead to higher utilization rates and lower freight rates. Option 2 – developing port competitiveness Countries with sea access can apply a wide range of policies that aim at increasing the operational (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:90)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:78)(cid:17)(cid:3) This includes decisions on the legal and institutional framework, the selection of an ownership model or the allocation of funds for infrastructure investments. The reforms should target all entities having a relevant role in the port, such as the landlord, regulator, operator, marketer and cargo handler, thus reducing port charges related to each function. The negotiation of a balanced concession agreement between the terminal operator and the responsible regulatory institution is a critical element when shaping a performance-orientated port business environment. This should include appropriate incentives that promote a continuous improvement of operations, competitive price setting mechanisms and a comprehensive performance monitoring system. 80 REVIEW OF MARITIME TRANSPORT 2012 A. PORT THROUGHPUT Port throughput is usually measured in tons and by (cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:92)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:11)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:91)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:83)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:85)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:82)(cid:12)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:47)(cid:76)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:71)(cid:3) cargo is usually measured in tons or sometimes, in the case of oil, in barrels. Within the dry cargo sector there is bulk (coal, grain, iron ore, and the like) and break bulk (for example, general cargo, timber and containers). While it is B. RECENT PORT DEVELOPMENTS Port developments continue throughout the world at an uneven pace spurred on by national needs to import and export and a chance to seize a share of growing world seaborne trade through trans-shipment opportunities. The following sections are a brief overview of some of these developments organized alphabetically. The list is not exhaustive and the ports mentioned are merely meant to give regional perspective as well as illustrate the variety and type of developments. Other developments mentioned in previous issues of the Review of Maritime Transport continue at their pace. Virtually every port or government has a development plan or is presently engaged in infrastructure improvements. In Cameroon, work continues on the development of the Kribi port complex. The port will enable subregional integration through the Kribi–Bangui (the Central African Republic)–Kasangani (the Democratic Republic of the Congo) transport and development corridor.5 The port, which is being built as the main export point for oil pumped from Chad via pipeline, will also handle containerised cargo and cargo for Cameroon’s mining sector, such as bauxite, iron, nickel and cobalt. In China, port developments continue at a seemingly relentless pace. In Ukraine, the Government gave approval for a new port to be built at Lake Donuzlav in the Crimea. These landside users’ issues are in stark contrast with those of the seaside users. Landside users are constrained by the (cid:83)(cid:75)(cid:92)(cid:86)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) local or national governments and special-interest groups, whereas the seaside users are often able to make changes which may affect local communities (cid:69)(cid:88)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:69)(cid:77)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:70)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:50)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3) these areas concerns the port’s maritime customers, the shipowners. Ships are mobile and generally do not operate where they were constructed. Local communities centred around their creation points tend to see their advantages (for example, direct and indirect local employment) and not their operational disadvantages (pollution through emissions of gases, noise and light, among others). Ship construction is a large employer with strong roots in the local community and usually closely associated with other industrial plants, such as smelting. Ports, on the other hand, have lost a lot of their employee-based relations with the local community through retrenchment of labour brought about by mechanisation, streamlined business practices and a concentration on trans- (cid:86)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:83)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:85)(cid:68)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:3) (cid:116)(cid:3) (cid:90)(cid:75)(cid:76)(cid:70)(cid:75)(cid:3) (cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:79)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:75)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:72)(cid:90)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:80)(cid:92)(cid:17)(cid:3) (cid:44)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:71)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:3) communities are very sensitive to change, because ports rarely move and their facilities usually last for several decades. Port authorities or governments need to make informed choices about where to invest, the potential return on investment and the cost of each opportunity. Adaptation measures to possible negative impacts of climatic changes, such as sea- level rise and extreme weather events also need to be considered. The impact of increased ship size upon ports can be substantial. For example, the ports of Rotterdam and Shanghai have, over time, become constrained by the cities which have grown around them. Many ports have adapted to this changing pattern of trade by undertaking infrastructure development programmes to increase their market share of containerized cargo. Increased port throughput volumes may increase the port’s revenue collected through port dues or cargo handling fees. Local government may also see an increase in tax collection through higher trade volumes. However, increased cargo volumes driven by increased competition (between ports, exporters and importers, transport operators, and the like), could greatly improve the chances of return cargoes becoming available. This could lead to improved connectivity and lower transport costs per unit, to the (cid:69)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:88)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:55)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:87)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3) trade are well documented and include higher levels of peace, security, health and living standards.28 While this outcome may seem far removed from ship size, improvements which help lower transport costs could spill over into other areas. A gateway port relates to the import and export of cargo (usually national) into or from the hinterland, whereas transit ports refer to the same cargo destined or originating from or to other nearby countries. Trans-shipment cargo, however, stays within the port and thus does not need hinterland connections. For example, see: Intriligator, MD (2003). 96 REVIEW OF MARITIME TRANSPORT 2012 A. IMPORTANT DEVELOPMENTS IN TRANSPORT LAW Adoption of amendments to the 1996 Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims National legislation or international legal instruments may give shipowners and others linked with the operation of a ship the right to limit their liability in respect of certain claims, whatever the basis of liability may be. Under these so-called global limitation regimes, limits of liability are calculated using either the ship’s value or a value calculated on the basis of the size of the ship and in particular on the basis of the ship’s tonnage.1 The most important global limitation regimes are the Convention on Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims, 1976 (1976 LLMC),2 and the 1976 LLMC as amended by its 1996 Protocol3 (hereafter 1996 LLMC). (cid:37)(cid:82)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:28)(cid:26)(cid:25)(cid:3)(cid:47)(cid:47)(cid:48)(cid:38)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:20)(cid:28)(cid:28)(cid:25)(cid:3)(cid:47)(cid:47)(cid:48)(cid:38)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:72)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:86)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:3) limits of liability for two types of claims against shipowners (and certain other persons),4 namely, claims for loss of life (cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:77)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:92)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:83)(cid:85)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:92)(cid:3) (cid:71)(cid:68)(cid:80)(cid:68)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:388)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:17)5 In each case, the shipowner is entitled to limitation of liability except in certain cases of wilful misconduct.6 While the approach to limitation is the same under both regimes, there are important differences. In particular, the actual amounts to which the limitation is limited are higher under the 1996 LLMC. However, it should be noted that the amendments affect limitation of liability only under the 1996 LLMC.13 While many States have adopted the 1996 LLMC, some continue to adhere to the unamended 1976 LLMC, or the earlier International Convention Relating to the Limitation of the Liability of Owners of Seagoing Ships, 1957.14 Few (cid:54)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3) (cid:81)(cid:82)(cid:90)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:68)(cid:71)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:85)(cid:86)(cid:87)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:70)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:388)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:71)(cid:15)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3) (cid:44)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:3) (cid:38)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) (cid:73)(cid:82)(cid:85)(cid:3) (cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:56)(cid:81)(cid:76)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:38)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:53)(cid:88)(cid:79)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:74)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:82)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:47)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:68)(cid:87)(cid:76)(cid:82)(cid:81)(cid:3) of Liability of Owners of Seagoing Vessels, 1924. While each of the relevant Conventions deals with the issue of limitation of liability for maritime claims, there are substantive differences. B. REGULATORY DEVELOPMENTS RELATING TO THE REDUCTION OF GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS FROM INTERNATIONAL SHIPPING AND OTHER ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES 1. Reduction of greenhouse gas emissions from international shipping For several years, efforts aimed at establishing a regulatory regime to control and reduce emissions of

The 2012 Guidelines address some of the concerns that had been raised regarding the safety of the EEDI, both in debates among States at IMO discussions33 and within the shipping industry.34 The key concern in this respect had been that while the EEDI formula value can easily be met by using vessels with smaller, lower-power engines, these are potentially dangerous since they do not have enough reserve power available for emergency conditions, such as extreme weather or special manoeuvring in ports when necessary. The 2012 Guidelines on the method of calculation of the attained EEDI for new ships contain a provision which allows vessels to be built with whatever engine power the owner thinks necessary, as long as it is limited to provide a suitable shaft power to give the (cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:84)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:85)(cid:72)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:40)(cid:40)(cid:39)(cid:44)(cid:3)(cid:89)(cid:68)(cid:79)(cid:88)(cid:72)(cid:17)(cid:3)(cid:44)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:92)(cid:15)(cid:3)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:3)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:80)(cid:76)(cid:87)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:90)(cid:76)(cid:79)(cid:79)(cid:3) be deactivated or overridden so that more power can be used.35 An updated work plan36 was also agreed upon, for the (cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:89)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:82)(cid:83)(cid:80)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:87)(cid:3)(cid:82)(cid:73)(cid:3)(cid:73)(cid:88)(cid:85)(cid:87)(cid:75)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:3)(cid:74)(cid:88)(cid:76)(cid:71)(cid:72)(cid:79)(cid:76)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:86)(cid:3)(cid:68)(cid:81)(cid:71)(cid:3)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:72)(cid:85)(cid:74)(cid:92)(cid:16)(cid:72)(cid:73)(cid:388)(cid:70)(cid:76)(cid:72)(cid:81)(cid:70)(cid:92)(cid:3) frameworks for those ships not covered by the current EEDI regulations.
